instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange without battery, No liquid Damage
threads.message:
Hello everyone
Charger light works normal without battery. With battery attached it stays green. 
SMC Reset changes light like it supposed to. 

Energy consumption: 0.04 amps
S5 rail present, <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> high
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> High
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> present 
s4 rail is as dead as Steve Jobs. 

i do not really understand how <SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is generated
in schematics it goes from <CHIP>U8170</CHIP> NOSTUFF AND chip, AB is <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>(0V) <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL>(0v), both are low.
I have already desoldered bios chip and tested if i can read it. re-programmed it with "clear me" bios, nothing really changed. 
Now i'm trying to test clock signals to BIOS chip with a cheap Oscilloscope, but i do not really know if 20mhz is good enough for this purpose. 



Please don´t tell me SMC is dead - i have a greenlight and SMC Reset indication. :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange without battery, No liquid Damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange without battery, No liquid Damage
threads.message:
well, genuine 19V with "60-watt" chip :)
of course, i have a genuine brick too, but i don´t believe it could get <SIGNAL>S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL> if something was wrong in this area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange without battery, No liquid Damage
threads.message: No problem. Only thought I'd ask out of an abundance of caution.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange without battery, No liquid Damage
threads.message:
so it looks like this model has some weird relationships with the battery - i have found several posts on Russian forums, people claim that it does not autostart with no battery attached. This also means that if the battery died (overdischarged, for example), we will have this strange behavior. I guess Lous has rage-broken such board in some of his videos, thinking it is the CPU. 
can someone confirm if 00165 starts without the battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange without battery, No liquid Damage
threads.message: For me they always do, but I have read that for some they don't. So to rule this out get a known good battery that has a charge.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange without battery, No liquid Damage
threads.message:
small update.
battery change made no progress. charging works as normal (forget this "green light" thing, it was simply full, shame to me)
just after SMC "deep" reset, it's kind of starts with full fan and 0 on P1V05S0 and <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>.

can someone share 100% working "clear me" bios for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>(besides one on vinafix.com)?
also, i guess it#s better to replace MX25L64, would appreciate confirmed compatible chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange without battery, No liquid Damage
threads.message: Why are you messing with <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> now? I doubt that will be the issue if Vcore is not even there. You can just try any 00165 dump for testing first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange without battery, No liquid Damage
threads.message:
well, from my PC laptop experience i know that unreadable/corrupt bios may be the cause for dead Vcore/permanent S5 or even no charging light on some Compal platforms.
first thing i did with this board is i tested all rails and mosfets for shorts. this board has zero hints.


so is that possible that SMC override starts brain dead board and Vcore absence shows that CPU does not answer to its controller to set Vcore voltage?
i mean, sorry for such a stupid question, but what exactly is being overridden?
i'm getting really close to write "dead cpu " on this board :confused:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange without battery, No liquid Damage
threads.message: It is possible that the BIOS is corrupt, but unlikely. Just try another 00165 dump and see if it works. IF that solves the issue we can deal with ME region and serial numbers.
